document.masterDocTitle: Cryptochironomus Kieffer from Lake Winnipeg, Canada, with a review of Nearctic species (Diptera: Chironomidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Cryptochironomus Kieffer from Lake Winnipeg, Canada, with a review of Nearctic species (Diptera: Chironomidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Cryptochironomus fulvus
Curry 1958
: 435
,
Darby 1962
: 162
, nec Johannsen 1905 : 224 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined . CANADA : Manitoba, Heming Lake, female reared from larva,
2 .viii. 1967
, A.P. Wiens. Lake Winnipeg record: Beaver Creek,
1 male
,
19 .viii. 1971
.
The previously undescribed female is characterized by a wing length of about 2.4 mm , LR l of about 1.7 , and absence of frontal tubercles.

The hypopygium is illustrated by
Darby ( 1962 , fig. 49 )
and
Mason ( 1986 fig. 2 )
.
Total length 4.93 mm . Wing length 2.42 mm . Total length/Wing length 2.03 . Wing length/length of profemur 2.40 .
Head . AR 0.48 . Temporals 21 . Clypeus with 22 setae. Frontal tubercles absent. Palp lengths (microns): 37, 73, 267, 143, 240 .
Thorax . Antepronotum with 9 setae. Dorsocentrals 33 , acrostichals 21 , prealars 6 . Scutellum with 29 setae.
Wing . VR 1.11 . Brachiolum with 2 setae, R with 27 , R 1 with 23 , R 4 + 5 with 55 setae. Squama with 24 setae.

Legs . Sensilla chaeticae 25 on mid leg, 11 on hind leg. Lengths and proportions of legs as in
Table 4
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Lengths (in Î¼m) and proportions of legs of
Cryptochironomus curryi
sp. n.

fe ti ta 1 ta 2 ta 3 ta 4 ta 5 LR BV SV BR p 1 1009 714 1227 558 469 394 170 1.72 1.85 1.40 2.20 p 2 874 832 503 252 190 120 83 0.60 3.42 3.39 2.64 p 3 925 1126 748 340 286 167 110 0.66 3.10 2.74 4.58 Genitalia (
Fig. 8
A). Cercus 113 Âµm long. Gonocoxite IX bare. T IX with 58 setae. Segment X with 4 setae on each side. Notum 210 Âµm long. Seminal capsules 110 Âµm long, 67 Âµm wide.

Total length 6.5 mm (7.0 mm in
Curry 1958
: 435 , table 4 ).

Cephalothorax . Cephalic tubercles (
Fig. 6
B) fused at base, 418 Âµm long ( 500 Âµm in Curry, 590â€“648 Âµm in Mason), 350 Âµm wide at base; main branch 124 Âµm long, 68 Âµm wide below lateral branch, 25 Âµm wide below frontal seta; lateral branch 95 Âµm long; frontal seta 70 Âµm long.

Abdomen (
Fig. 6
A). Tergites and sternites not reticulated. Shagreen and chaetotaxy as illustrated. Caudal margin of T II with 38â€“41 hooklets to each side of 90 Âµm (Curry) â€“ 200 Âµm wide mesal interruption. Pedes spurii A present on S IVâ€“VI, longest spinules 23 Âµm on IV, 6â€“7 Âµm on Vâ€“VI. Caudal margins of T IIIâ€“VII (VIII in male according to Curry) respectively with the following numbers of spines (lengths in parentheses): 41 ( 9 Âµm), 49 ( 9 Âµm), 48 ( 12 Âµm), 37 ( 16 Âµm), 32 ( 14 Âµm). Caudal margins of S II with 24 , up to 7 Âµm long spines; of S III with 10 , up to 4 Âµm long; of VII with 20 , up to 14 Âµm long spines; other sternites without caudal spines. Caudomedian projection of anal lobe 240 Âµm long, 240 Âµm wide at base; with 56 Âµm long, 18 Âµm wide branches. Genital sac with 30 Âµm long, 30 Âµm wide apical point. Fringe of anal lobe with 73 filaments ( 64â€“82 in Mason).

Head . Antenna as in
Fig. 8
B. Lengths of antennal segments (in Âµm): 72, 36, 30, 4, 4 . AR 0.97 ( 0.95â€“1.15 in Mason, 0.95 in
Curry 1958
: 435 , table 3 ). Basal antennal segment 27 Âµm wide, 2.00 times as long as second segment, ring organ 40 Âµm from base. Preapical blade of second segment 46 Âµm long, apical style 9 Âµm long. Labrum (
Fig. 8
C) with 33 Âµm long labral sensilla, S
I 30
Âµm, S
II 58
Âµm long. Premandible 106 Âµm long ( 110 in Curry). Mandible (
Fig. 8
D) 148 Âµm long ( 144 in Mason, 140 Âµm in Curry), with 36 Âµm long apical tooth which is 0.24 times as long as mandible. Basal segment of maxillary palp 56 Âµm long, 21 Âµm wide. Median tooth of mentum (
Fig. 8
E), including darker lateral accessory teeth, 48 Âµm wide. Ventromental plates 156 Âµm wide, 42 Âµm long, 3.71 times as wide as long ( 170 Âµm wide, 40 Âµm long in Curry). Postmentum 188 Âµm long. Abdomen . Procercus 34 Âµm wide, with 555 Âµm long anal setae.

Distribution and ecology .
Curry ( 1958 , table 2 )
mentions the species (as
C. fulvus
) from the silty littoral and sublittoral of a lake and from a pond in Michigan.
Darby ( 1962 : 162 )
found the species (as
Tendipes fulvus
) in rice fields in California where most of the larvae occurred in deep standing or slowly flowing water. Mason ( 1983 : 406 ) collected the species from sandy substrates in Saskatchewan River and Tobin Lake. Thus the only certain records for
C. curryi
are Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Michigan, and California. However, the males almost certainly are included in previous records of
C. fulvus
.
